origin_history: Seeded on Nov 13, 2025 as a ring around the broccoli tray.
Added potting mix on top of sand-heavy layer for better moisture and pH balance.
Reseeded chives after soil improvement to support proper germination.
whats_been_logged: The chives progressed from initial germination into early post-emergence development, with thin green shoots breaking the soil surface and reappearing after intermittent burial from wind and rain. While emergence has been uneven and sparse due to surface disturbance, surviving seedlings remain green and upright, indicating continued viability as roots establish in the shared window box.
current_state: The chive seedlings are very small and currently sparse, with several shoots partially buried or pinned by soil displaced from wind and rain. Only a few short green tips are visible above the surface after gentle brushing, while others remain covered. Color remains healthy with no collapse, yellowing, or damping-off, indicating the seedlings are alive and anchored despite limited visible top growth.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Individual Blade Becomes a Small Tuft
Additional Blades Emerging From the Same Base
Blades Thickening and Standing More Firmly
Dense Clump Forming at the Base

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 59°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chive section remains extremely sparse with only a few thin green blades visible above the soil. The surface layer appears very dry and crusty/crumbly, consistent with rapid dry-down in bright sun. The probe indicates the root zone is currently too dry for fragile seedlings to remain stable, supporting the decision to transplant for better moisture control.
journal.actions: Apply 2 cups of water slowly over the chive band 15–20 minutes before lifting to bind the root zone and reduce root tearing. Keep the lifted root mass shaded from direct sun while transplanting today.
journal.next_steps: After transplanting, keep the plant in bright shade or morning-only sun for 48 hours to reduce stress and stabilize moisture. Recheck a probe reading tomorrow late morning once the medium settles around the roots and continue monitoring for new green tips over the next week.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed transplant timing and confirmed moisture stability is the urgent priority for survival. Reviewed post-transplant condition and confirmed the seedlings look viable in the new container, with guidance to keep the pot in bright shade and maintain gentle surface moisture over the next 48 hours.
follow_up: [6:16 PM] Transplanted the surviving chive seedlings into an old Bonnie Plant Foodie Fresh 25 oz round pot with at least 8 drainage holes to improve moisture stability and reduce rapid dry-down.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the chive section showing very sparse surviving green blades and a dry, crusty soil surface in the window box.
Overhead view after transplant showing several surviving chive blades spaced across the newly filled pot with a darker, evenly moist surface layer.
photos.tags: chives, seedlings, transplant, overhead, moist-soil, recovery-pot

photos.caption: Side-angle view of the transplanted chive seedlings showing thin green blades standing above a freshly settled, uniform soil surface in the 25 oz pot.
Wider view of the recovery pot showing the full planting area with multiple visible chive shoots and improved moisture retention compared to the window box.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 59°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chive section remains extremely sparse with only a few thin green blades visible above the soil. The surface layer appears very dry and crusty/crumbly, consistent with rapid dry-down in bright sun. The probe indicates the root zone is currently too dry for fragile seedlings to remain stable, supporting the decision to transplant for better moisture control.
journal.actions: Apply 2 cups of water slowly over the chive band 15–20 minutes before lifting to bind the root zone and reduce root tearing. Keep the lifted root mass shaded from direct sun while transplanting today.
journal.next_steps: After transplanting, keep the plant in bright shade or morning-only sun for 48 hours to reduce stress and stabilize moisture. Recheck a probe reading tomorrow late morning once the medium settles around the roots and continue monitoring for new green tips over the next week.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the chive section showing very sparse surviving green blades and a dry, crusty soil surface in the window box.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chive seedlings remain sparse but several thin green blades are still visible across the band. The soil surface appears drier and lighter than the previous day with a chunky texture, consistent with a healthy dry-down after prior saturation. The pH reading of 0.00 is treated as a probe contact failure rather than true soil pH, as the remaining nutrient and moisture values are coherent.
journal.actions: Apply 1/2 cup of water gently over the chive band early tomorrow morning to prevent surface crusting and protect seedlings during a hot, sunny day. Do not fertilize or disturb the soil surface after watering.
journal.next_steps: Recheck the probe reading tomorrow late morning from a slightly different spot in the chive band to confirm pH and track moisture. Maintain moisture between 35.00 and 55.00, and increase watering only if moisture drops below 30.00 on a sunny day.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether watering is needed early the following morning after an ideal moisture reading and confirmed that a very small surface-focused watering is appropriate to prevent crusting and protect fragile seedlings during another hot, sunny day.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the window box showing a sparse chive section with several thin green blades still visible across a drier, lighter soil surface following a healthy dry-down.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 58°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chive seedlings remain very small and sparse, with a few thin green blades still visible above the soil surface. The soil appears dark and clumpy following morning watering, consistent with the elevated moisture reading. No yellowing, collapse, or damping-off is visible, and the seedlings that remain are green and upright despite slow establishment. Some diluted Purived fertilizer may have lightly contacted this section during nearby broccoli feeding, but nutrient and salt readings remain within a safe range.
journal.actions: Do not water today or tomorrow morning. Allow the window box to dry down naturally and maintain surface stability by avoiding disturbance.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow late morning and continue withholding water until moisture drops to 40.00 or below. Monitor seedlings for continued green color and look for tuft formation (multiple blades emerging from the same base) as moisture stabilizes.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether a 6:00 AM watering is needed tomorrow morning and confirmed it should be skipped because the soil is still very wet today. Emphasized that allowing a gentle dry-down will better support these fragile seedlings and reduce risk from prolonged saturation.

photos.caption: Overhead view of the window box showing very sparse chive seedlings with a few thin green blades visible across a dark, recently watered soil surface.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 80°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: The chive seedlings remain very small and sparse, with several tiny green blades still visible above the soil surface. The surface layer appears dry and chunky with bark pieces and uneven texture, which can contribute to burial and abrasion of the shallow shoots during wind or watering. No yellowing, collapse, or damping-off is visible in the remaining blades.
journal.actions: Apply 1 cup of water slowly and evenly across the chive band to rehydrate the top layer and reduce surface crusting. Do not disturb or brush the soil surface after watering.
journal.next_steps: Visually check tomorrow midday to confirm green tips remain visible and are not being reburied. Take the next probe reading from a slightly different spot in the same chive band to confirm stability. Water only if moisture drops to 30.00 or below on a sunny day.

photos.caption: Close-up of the chive section showing very sparse, short green blades emerging through a dry, chunky soil surface with bark pieces and uneven texture.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84°F dropping to around 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings are very low and sparse following wind and rain that pushed dry soil across the surface, partially burying the shoots. A few tiny green tips are visible after lightly brushing soil aside, but many seedlings appear pinned down or re-covered by surface material. Rain occurred on and off this morning from 5:45 AM to 8:30 AM (drizzle to heavy at times). The pH reading of 2.50 is an extreme outlier and is treated as likely probe contact error rather than true soil pH.
journal.actions: Do not water tonight. Continue gentle surface brushing only as needed to uncover shoot tips after wind/rain without disturbing roots.
journal.next_steps: Recheck a probe reading tomorrow morning from a slightly different spot to confirm pH and track moisture dry-down. Consider watering only if moisture drops to 30.00 or below and no rain is expected that day.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User asked whether seedlings are still visible and whether they were lost after being covered by wind/rain; confirmed a few tiny green tips are visible and explained that repeated burial can make seedlings appear shorter and sparser without meaning they are dead. Evaluated watering at 6:58 PM and advised against watering tonight because moisture was still moderate at 10:27 AM, only ~8.5 hours have passed, and overnight conditions favor drying less than tomorrow’s sun.

photos.caption: Window box surface showing mostly covered chive area with only a few tiny green tips visible after wind/rain moved dry soil across the seedlings.
Close-up of the chive section showing sparse, very short green tips peeking through a disturbed soil surface after brushing soil aside.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings remain small but show improved posture with several blades standing upright and clearly anchored. Newer, shorter blades are visible close to the soil surface alongside slightly taller blades, indicating early tuft formation. Soil has dried into an ideal range despite intermittent rain from 5:45 AM to 8:30 AM, confirming good drainage. No yellowing, collapse, or damping-off is present.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize. Maintain current conditions and allow natural growth progression.
journal.next_steps: Continue monitoring moisture and maintain readings near the 30–40 mS/cm range. Over the next week, watch for blade thickening and multiple blades emerging from the same base.

photos.caption: Top-down view showing small but upright chive seedlings with improved posture and early signs of multiple blades near the soil surface.
Close-up view of chive seedlings emerging through drying soil, showing healthy green color and firm anchoring after rainfall.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings remain small but intact, with several thin green blades visible across the section. Some blades are upright while others rest close to the soil surface. Color remains healthy with no yellowing, collapse, or damping-off. Soil surface appears dark and moist following recent rain and high moisture retention.
journal.actions: Do not water, fertilize, or disturb the soil. Allow moisture levels to decline naturally.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture daily and wait to water until readings fall into the 40–45 mS/cm range. Expect improved posture and blade thickening once excess moisture resolves.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether chives will naturally become denser or require reseeding. Explained that each seedling will first thicken, then produce additional blades from the same base, forming a tuft that eventually becomes a dense clump. Reseeding is not needed at this stage.

photos.caption: Young chive seedlings with thin green blades showing normal early establishment under wet soil conditions.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings show multiple thin green blades with mild leaning, consistent with elevated moisture and warm soil following a full window box fertilization using diluted Purived 4-5-5. Color remains healthy and uniformly green with no yellowing, collapse, or damping-off. Broccoli leaves that had been shading the chive section were cut back, improving light penetration across the planter and reducing canopy pressure on the chives.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize. Allow soil moisture and nutrient levels to stabilize naturally following feeding.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture over the next 48–72 hours and wait to water until readings drop below 40 mS/cm. Observe blade posture as increased light encourages more upright growth.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing thin green blades with mild leaning after fertilization and improved light from broccoli pruning.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings are well established with multiple thin, upright green blades emerging across the right band. Growth appears uniform with no signs of stretch, discoloration, or damping-off. Partial shade from adjacent broccoli provides intermittent cover without suppressing development.
journal.actions: Do not water or disturb the seedlings. Leave broccoli canopy intact, as current shading is acceptable and protective at this stage.
journal.next_steps: Monitor blade thickness and posture over the next 7–10 days. Reassess light competition only if chives become pale or excessively floppy. Recheck moisture tomorrow morning.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether shading from broccoli is harmful; confirmed partial shade is acceptable and moving chives is not recommended at this stage.

photos.caption: Close view of chive seedlings showing thin, upright green blades emerging across the right section.
Wider view showing chive section partially shaded by adjacent broccoli leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings continue healthy early growth with an increase in visible blades and steady upright posture. The soil surface shows improved texture and even moisture distribution following recent amendments. No signs of damping-off, discoloration, or stress are present. The realistic pH reading confirms strong probe contact and balanced soil conditions.
journal.actions: No watering or amendments applied today as moisture is ideal. Lightly stabilize any leaning seedlings with a small pinch of loose potting mix if needed.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning as the cooler, sunny forecast may create a moderate dry-down. Water only when moisture falls below 30 mS/cm. Continue monitoring for new sprouts as the improved soil structure supports increased germination.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing fuller early growth across an evenly moist, aerated soil surface.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings remain healthy with upright green blades and natural early-stage leaning. The soil surface shows clear improvement after loosening and adding Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix, reducing the compaction seen in the original topsoil and sand blend. The probe reading reflects markedly better soil contact, with pH returning to a realistic range and moisture in a moderate dry-down. No signs of damping-off, discoloration, or stress are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today as rain is expected and current moisture is sufficient. Avoid further disturbance of the soil so seedlings can anchor securely.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after rainfall to ensure levels stay below saturation. Continue monitoring seedling posture as roots deepen, and expect additional sprouts over the next several days as the improved soil texture supports more even germination.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing healthy green growth after soil loosening and the addition of potting mix.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings appear healthy, upright, and slightly taller than the previous day. Color remains vibrant with no signs of wilt or discoloration. Soil surface is evenly moist following recent weather, and sprouts show normal early-stage leaning as roots establish more deeply. The elevated pH value reflects partial probe contact rather than true soil alkalinity.
journal.actions: No watering or amendments applied today as moisture is ideal and rain is expected later.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after tonight's rainfall and allow natural dry-down if readings rise above the mid-70s. Continue monitoring seedling uprightness as roots anchor more firmly.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings with healthy upright blades across an evenly moist soil surface.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 86°F dropping to 64°F overnight. Patchy fog early, calm wind becoming south 5–8 mph.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear upright, green, and evenly progressing with no signs of water stress such as collapse, wilt, or discoloration. The soil surface is dry in the upper layer, but the overall moisture reading indicates adequate hydration in the deeper root zone. Extremely high pH values and very low EC and salt readings reflect limited probe contact with moist soil rather than true soil chemistry, as the mix was dry in spots prior to insertion. Seedlings remain healthy with good turgor, and the bark-heavy mix continues to dry unevenly without negatively affecting growth.
journal.actions: Do not water today based on sufficient moisture levels in the active root zone.
journal.next_steps: Do not water until moisture drops below the mid-20s range or seedlings display clear wilt. Allow the soil to continue its natural dry-down cycle and avoid adding water while the deeper layer remains adequately moist.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings upright and well-colored across a partially dry soil surface.
Additional view of chive sprouts showing healthy elongation and no signs of drought stress.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings remain upright and healthy with clear early growth, showing elongation and strong green color. The soil was bone dry earlier in the afternoon, preventing any probe readings, but after watering and allowing time for moisture redistribution the sensor registered normally. Some sprouts lean slightly due to earlier dryness and wind, but no signs of wilt, yellowing, or damping-off are present. The added soil continues to stabilize the surface. A small soil-dwelling bug was visible in the close-up image; its size and movement pattern suggest a harmless springtail or similar microarthropod common in organic mixes.
journal.actions: Watered earlier in the afternoon to restore moisture after the soil became too dry for readings.
journal.next_steps: Do not water again tonight. Monitor the upper soil layer and irrigate lightly once it turns dry-gray. Continue filling probe voids as needed and avoid overwatering while the deeper soil remains saturated.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing healthy elongation after rehydration of the previously dry soil.
View of chive sprouts across a moist soil surface following watering.
Close-up of seedlings and soil texture with visible organic bark components.
Close-up image showing a small soil-dwelling insect consistent with harmless springtail activity.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear upright and healthy, showing continued early growth with no signs of stress, collapse, or discoloration. The soil surface is visibly dry and crumbly, especially in the upper layer, while deeper layers appear slightly darker and more hydrated. The probe readings returned zeros for pH and moisture and unusually low nutrient values, consistent with insufficient soil contact and the bark-heavy mix creating air gaps around the sensor. This reflects a measurement failure due to dryness at contact points rather than an actual zero-moisture soil state.
journal.actions: No watering was recorded at this time.
journal.next_steps: Apply a light surface watering to rehydrate the upper layer without saturating the deeper soil. Continue filling probe voids with soil to maintain stable surface structure.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings standing upright with visible early growth across a dry soil surface.
Close view of chive sprouts growing through a bark-heavy mix with dry upper-layer texture.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observations: Seedlings show continued elongation with healthy green color and no signs of collapse or foliar stress. Soil is fully saturated, likely from retained moisture rather than recent watering. Some leaning is present due to gusty conditions, but overall growth remains stable.
journal.actions: Do not water today given saturated soil conditions.
journal.next_steps: Allow soil to dry slightly over the next 24 hours before considering additional watering. Avoid disturbing the upper layer until moisture levels decline from saturation.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing healthy elongation across a saturated soil surface.
Close view of chive sprouts leaning slightly due to wind but maintaining good color.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 65°F overnight. Rain expected around 6:00 PM.
journal.observations: Seedlings continue healthy elongation with stronger vertical growth and good green color. Soil stability has improved since adding mix to fill probe holes, and seedlings are better anchored. Slight leaning due to wind is normal at this stage. No indicators of stress, wilt, or disease.
journal.actions: Do not water today.
journal.next_steps: Do not water before evening rain. Allow storm moisture to naturally settle the newly added soil. Avoid additional probe insertions until soil stabilizes.

photos.caption: Healthy chive seedlings showing upright early growth across improved soil surface.
Close view of sprouts with soil leveled from previous probe voids.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight. Thunderstorms expected later in the day.
journal.observations: Seedlings show continued upright early growth with strong green color. Soil surface appears uneven but improving as newly added soil fills pockets created by the wide probe. Moisture level is moderate and appropriate for this stage. No signs of stress, fungal issues, or nutrient imbalance.
journal.actions: Do not water today.
journal.next_steps: Avoid watering before thunderstorms arrive. Let rainfall hydrate and settle the soil naturally. Continue gentle soil leveling if probe holes reopen.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings upright in moderate moisture conditions before forecasted storms.
Soil surface showing improvement as added mix fills probe-created gaps.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear healthy and clearly taller than the previous day, entering a stronger elongation phase. Soil surface is dry but deeper moisture is present, consistent with the elevated probe moisture reading. Seedlings show no bending from drought and no discoloration, indicating adequate hydration despite surface dryness.
journal.actions: Watered earlier at 2:33 PM due to very dry upper soil conditions.
journal.next_steps: Allow soil to dry gently before the next watering. Avoid overwatering while deeper moisture remains high.

photos.caption: Chive seedlings showing continued elongation on a dry surface layer.
Sprouts upright with healthy coloration despite uneven soil drying.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: More sprouts are visible across the right section, with early seedlings standing taller and showing healthy color. Soil surface is dry despite high moisture readings, indicating deeper wet pockets below a drying top layer. No stress signals, mold, or compaction present.
journal.actions: Light watering was done earlier in the morning to rehydrate a dry and crumbly surface.
journal.next_steps: Allow the upper layer to dry slightly before the next watering, maintaining moderate moisture throughout the root zone.

photos.caption: Emerging chive seedlings showing upright early growth following surface watering.
Close view of sprouts emerging through a bark-heavy potting mix.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: A larger number of chive sprouts are now visible across the right section, showing healthy bright-green emergence. The soil surface appears dry despite the high moisture reading, suggesting deeper moisture pockets below a drying top layer. Seedlings look strong with no signs of mold, algae, or stress.
journal.actions: No watering applied at this time to allow surface layer to continue drying while deeper moisture supports roots.
journal.next_steps: Light surface watering may be needed if the top layer continues to dry while deeper moisture remains high. Continue monitoring moisture distribution and seedling uprightness over the next 24–48 hours.

photos.caption: Chive section showing multiple new sprouts emerging through a dry surface layer.
Close view of emerging chive seedlings among bark-heavy soil.
Additional sprouts visible despite the dry upper layer, indicating uneven moisture distribution.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: Multiple definite chive sprouts have emerged, marking the transition from pre-germination into early germination. Soil is currently very wet, which poses a risk for damping-off, but seedlings appear healthy with no signs of mold or surface crusting. pH remains slightly acidic but within a tolerable range for newly germinated chives.
journal.actions: No watering applied to avoid further saturating the germination zone. Photos taken to document emergence.
journal.next_steps: Allow soil moisture to drop toward 50–60 mS/cm before watering again. Monitor sprouts over the next 48 hours to ensure they remain upright and free of damping-off symptoms.

photos.caption: Close-up showing newly emerged chive sprouts near the soil surface.
Early chive seedlings emerging between soil particles under filtered light.
Wider view of the chive section showing multiple germination points.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil moisture has stabilized into the ideal mid-range for germination, and pH continues trending upward from previous lows, supporting healthier conditions for chive sprouts. No emergence is visible yet, which remains normal at day eight following reseeding. The soil surface appears loose enough for germination, with no signs of mold, pests, or crusting.
journal.actions: No watering applied to maintain proper germination moisture. Continued full-sun exposure.
journal.next_steps: Monitor moisture closely and avoid watering until the upper layer begins to dry. Expect possible first emergence within the coming week as pH and moisture stabilize.

photos.caption: Chives soil surface with no visible sprouts yet and good sun exposure.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil remains moist and well-mixed with organic material visible at the surface. No sprouts are visible yet but the moisture level is adequate for germination. pH remains slightly acidic but within an acceptable short-term range.
journal.actions: No watering or adjustments made to avoid over-saturating the germination zone.
journal.next_steps: Allow the soil to dry slightly before the next watering and continue monitoring for first emergence.

photos.caption: Chives area showing moist soil and stable surface texture.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82–85°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil is extremely moist and nutrient-rich but still structurally sound with no obvious pooling. No chive sprouts are visible yet, which is still consistent with the early germination period. The higher fertility and salt values indicate this side received more nutrient-dense material during amendment.
journal.actions: No watering or fertilizing applied to avoid further saturation and nutrient buildup.
journal.next_steps: Allow moisture levels to fall naturally before watering again and continue watching for first emergence over the next week.

photos.caption: Chives soil surface showing high moisture and no visible sprouts.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: No sprouts are visible in the right chive band, but the soil appears moderately moist with good texture and aeration. pH is still slightly acidic but trending upward compared with earlier readings. No surface mold, algae, or pest activity is evident.
journal.actions: No watering or amendments applied in order to keep conditions steady.
journal.next_steps: Recheck pH and moisture within 24 hours and continue monitoring for the first emergence of seedlings.

photos.caption: Right chive section with stable moisture and no emergence yet.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: Right chive section is very wet with high salt and fertility readings, yet the soil still appears structurally intact. No visible germination has occurred, which remains normal at this early stage. The higher nutrient and moisture levels distinguish this side from the rest of the planter.
journal.actions: No water or fertilizer added to prevent further oversaturation.
journal.next_steps: Allow moisture to decline toward more moderate levels before watering again and watch for germination as pH and salts normalize.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Noted that the right side is wetter and more nutrient-rich, requiring time to dry somewhat before additional watering.

photos.caption: Right chive edge showing dark, saturated soil and no sprouts.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The right chive band remains unsprouted with slightly moist soil following recent amendments. pH is still quite low, which could limit early germination if not gradually corrected. Soil texture looks improved compared with the original sand-heavy mix.
journal.actions: No direct lime application made yet; readings taken to guide future pH adjustment.
journal.next_steps: Plan a very light lime application once moisture stabilizes and recheck pH within 48–72 hours.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Reviewed that chives prefer a more neutral pH and that current acidity is being monitored before correcting.

photos.caption: Tray overview including right chive band prior to any visible germination.

journal.conditions: Mild fall day with partial sun and comfortable temperatures.
journal.observations: Right chive section has been freshly reseeded across the amended soil edge, matching the left side. The surface is moist and leveled, with no signs of crusting or disturbance.
journal.actions: Reseeded chives evenly across the right edge of the planter into the improved soil layer.
journal.next_steps: Maintain consistent moisture at the surface and avoid disturbing this section while germination begins over the coming weeks.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Confirmed that this reseeding date also applies to the right chive band around the broccoli.

photos.caption: Right edge of the planter after chive reseeding.

journal.conditions: Cool, mostly sunny fall day with light breeze.
journal.observations: Right chive edge is still unseeded, showing the same dry, sand-heavy conditions as the rest of the tray. The soil appears light and quick to dry, with low fertility and an alkaline pH that is not ideal for chive seeds.
journal.actions: Participated in the overall tray amendment where about two inches of the sand/soil mix were removed and replaced with potting mix, followed by thorough watering.
journal.next_steps: Allow the new soil layer to settle and stabilize before sowing chive seed in this section.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed the limitations of the original sand/soil blend and the need for richer potting mix before planting.

photos.caption: Planter edge on the right prior to chive seeding, showing light, dry soil.

journal.conditions: Cool, bright afternoon with full sun on the planter.
journal.observations: Right chive edge appears as bare soil around the broccoli row with no visible germination from the earlier sowing attempt. The sand/soil blend is only lightly damp and seems nutritionally poor.
journal.actions: No specific action taken on the right band yet; conditions documented to guide later soil improvements and reseeding.
journal.next_steps: Plan to amend the soil with potting mix and prepare this band for a fresh, more successful chive sowing.

photos.caption: Initial tray view showing broccoli center and bare right edge where chives will be reseeded.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: Chive seedlings appear significantly more sparse and shorter today, with many previously visible shoots no longer apparent after repeated wind, rain, and surface soil movement. Only a few very short green blades remain visible above the soil surface. Remaining blades retain healthy green color with no yellowing, collapse, or damping-off observed. Surface soil appears dry and lightly crusted despite moderate moisture earlier in the morning, consistent with top-layer drying in a shallow window box.
journal.actions: Light surface watering recommended now to rehydrate the top inch of soil and protect remaining seedlings from crown desiccation. No fertilization, reseeding, or soil disturbance performed.
journal.next_steps: Maintain moisture stability and avoid further disturbance. Monitor remaining seedlings over the next 24–48 hours for continued green color and upright posture before making any reseeding decisions.
journal.q_and_a_summary: User expressed concern that chive seedlings are fading quickly. Assessment confirmed significant stress from repeated burial and surface drying but noted remaining viable green blades. Watering was recommended immediately due to elapsed time since the morning probe reading, full sun exposure, and seedling root depth.

photos.caption: Window box showing very sparse chive seedlings with only a few short green blades visible after wind and rain displaced surface soil.
